bestBHT.bht: Christ's work of opening a new and living way for us to enter into God's presence is remarkable. Through his Incarnation and Death, he dedicated this freshly killed and newly made way for us to have boldness and access to God himself. By following Christ, we are led to the enjoyment of all the good things of God, as we walk in him, the way that infallibly leads to eternal life. Ultimately, Christ's flesh becomes the door and the way for us to find and commune with the divine.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Translate, 'which (entering) He has consecrated (not as though it were already existing, but has been the first to open, INAUGURATED as a new thing
It is a living hope that we have, producing not dead, but living, works
Christ's ascension is our promotion; and whither the glory of the Head hath preceded, thither the hope of the body, too, is called
Albert Barnes: It was a way which was recently disclosed, and which had all the freshness of novelty. It is called a 'living way,' because it is a method that imparts life, or because it leads to life and happiness.
The way by Christ was, however, always open. His blood was, as it were, always warm, and as if it had been recently shed.
The simple idea which seems to have been in the mind of the apostle was, that the veil of the temple and the body of Jesus were alike in this respect, that they were the medium of access to God.
Marvin Vincent: Having boldness for the entrance which he has inaugurated (or opened) for us - a way new and living.
Christ's work does not stop short of the believer's complete access to God himself.
His flesh was the state through which he had to pass before he entered heaven for us.
John Calvin: The divinity, though hid in the flesh of Christ, yet leads us even into heaven.
Nor can any one find God except he to whom the man Christ becomes the door and the way.

Thus we are reminded, that Christ’s glory is not to be estimated according to the external appearance of his flesh; nor is his flesh to be despised, because it conceals as a veil the majesty of God, while it is also that which conducts us to the enjoyment of all the good things of God.
Archibald T. Robertson: This 'new' (προσφατον, freshly killed, newly made, from προς and the root of φατος, in the papyri, only here in N.T.) and 'living' (ζωσαν) Jesus opened ('dedicated') for us by his Incarnation and Death for us."
Thus he fulfilled God's promise of the 'New Covenant' (Hebrews 8:7-13) in Jeremiah.
At any rate because of the coming of Christ in the flesh we have the new way opened for access to God (Hebrews 2:17; Hebrews 4:16).
John Gill: Christ is a 'living way'; in opposition to the dead carcasses of slain beasts, and to the dead and killing letter of the law; Christ gives life to all his people; and all that walk in him, the way, live; and none in this way ever die; it leads to eternal life, and infallibly brings them thither.

the matter of which that was made, was fine twined linen, which the Jews y say was of thread six times doubled; which may denote the holiness of Christ's human nature; the strength, courage, and steadfastness of it, under all its sorrows and sufferings; and the purity and duration of his righteousness

the vail was of cunning work, which may intend the curious workmanship of Christ's human nature, and the graces of the Spirit, with which it is adorned; and it was made with 'cherubim', pointing to the ministration of angels, both to Christ, and to his people.
John Wesley: By a living way — The way of faith, whereby we live indeed.
Which he hath consecrated — Prepared, dedicated, and established for us.

Through the veil, that is, his flesh — As by rending the veil in the temple, the holy of holies became visible and accessible; so by wounding the body of Christ, the God of heaven was manifested, and the way to heaven opened.

bhtAttempts.bht: Christ's work of opening a new and living way for us to enter into God's presence is remarkable. His flesh, being the conduit through which he passed before entering heaven, was the instrument that fulfilled God's promise of the New Covenant. Through his Incarnation and Death, he dedicated this freshly killed and newly made way for us to have boldness and access to God himself. It is an extraordinary privilege, and through Christ's blood, shed like the freshness of a recent sacrifice, we are granted this living hope, producing not dead, but living, works. By following Christ, we are led to the enjoyment of all the good things of God, as we walk in him, the way that infallibly leads to eternal life. Ultimately, Christ's flesh, though veiling the majesty of God, becomes the door and the way for us to find and commune with the divine.

Ultimately, Christ's flesh becomes the door and the way for us to find and commune with the divine.

Through his Incarnation and Death, he dedicated this freshly killed and newly made way for us to have boldness and access to God himself. By following Christ, we are led to the enjoyment of all the good things of God, as we walk in him, the way that infallibly leads to eternal life. Ultimately, Christ's flesh becomes the door and the way for us to find and commune with the divine.

Christ's work of opening a new and living way for us to enter into God's presence is remarkable. Through his Incarnation and Death, he dedicated this freshly killed and newly made way for us to have boldness and access to God himself. By following Christ, we are led to the enjoyment of all the good things of God, as we walk in him, the way that infallibly leads to eternal life. Ultimately, Christ's flesh becomes the door and the way for us to find and commune with the divine.

By entering through Christ's consecrated way, we are granted the privilege of boldness and access to God himself. Christ's Incarnation and Death inaugurated a new and living way, fulfilling the promise of the New Covenant. Through his flesh, Christ became the door and the way for us to find and commune with the divine. Walking in this infallible path of faith leads us to the enjoyment of all the good things of God and ultimately to eternal life.
